I notice swss will influence this service.
```
ExecStartPre=/bin/bash -c "/usr/share/sonic/device/$(sonic-cfggen -H -v DEVICE_METADATA.localhost.platform)/hw-management start"
ExecStopPost=/bin/bash -c "/usr/share/sonic/device/$(sonic-cfggen -H -v DEVICE_METADATA.localhost.platform)/hw-management stop"
```
Suggest make them consistent with each other. #Closed

> I notice swss will influence this service.
> ...
> Suggest make them consistent with each other.

There is difference between this two starts.
Before updategraph is needed probably only once - on config creation when eeprom cache is missing. It is started without SDK module loaded (to start faster) and some components may not work.
Swss is wrapped in "full start" and should happen on every boot/restart
All hw-management services are fine after first partial start followed by full start
can you resolve the build issue
retest this please
you need to modify the start.sh to start staticd
both model are supported, if it is unified configuration model, then use frr.conf. if it is separated configuration model, then use zebra.conf, bgpd.conf, and staticd.conf.
about FRR-pythontools, don't we have python3 installed in the frr docker?

After this PR [https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/2807](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/2807), python3 is only available in snmp docker image (3.6). What is the motivate of using FRR-pythontools? If really needed, I propose 2 options:
1. install python3.6 into docker-base image
2. install Debian vanilla python3.5.3-1 in Stretch docker-base.

---
In reply to: [492426979](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/2899#issuecomment-492426979) [](ancestors = 492426979)

> you need to modify the start.sh to start staticd

I think I've it here: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/2899/files#diff-2faaa492fd949e4b9f384eb592a81bcbR35

> After this PR #2807, python3 is only available in snmp docker image (3.6). What is the motivate of using FRR-pythontools? If really needed, I propose 2 options:
> 
> install python3.6 into docker-base image
> install Debian vanilla python3.5.3-1 in Stretch docker-base.
> 
> 
> In reply to: 492426979 [](ancestors = 492426979)

I don't think we need frr-pythontools.
Currently it's contains only https://github.com/Azure/sonic-frr/blob/88351c8f6df5450e9098f773813738f62abb2f5e/tools/frr-reload.py
I think we can run in on python2.7 and we can install it inside of dockerfile if we need it.
We need more free space for our Jenkins

> both model are supported, if it is unified configuration model, then use frr.conf. if it is separated configuration model, then use zebra.conf, bgpd.conf, and staticd.conf.

Currently frr.conf has preference over bgpd.conf/zebra.com/staticd.conf

I can repro this issue on the master branch. The issue looks like to be even though the port channel is shutdown, but the member port are not shutdown. Then, the member ports still receive the lacp pdu and make the member port to be selected. 

another approach to fix the problem is to shutdown the member ports when port channel is administrative down.

It looks VS docker change is needed to use frr? supervisord.conf is hardcoded with quagga path.
current pr won't work in case the routing stack is quagga, need to figure out a way to support both quagga and frr.
@jipanyang , for first 2, check #2870

@jipanyang  Can you elaborate this "zebra/bgpd will be restarted automatically by watchfrr. it will affect warm reboot function."?  What exactly the impact?  
There were reasons the daemons were restarted:  crashed or hang etc. And I assume we want the daemons to be restarted to recover. They are agnostic to warm-restart/reboot. 

In case BGP restart, zebra is supposed to remove all routes from kernel and SONiC. This is BGP feature gap that if we need support unplanned warm restart.

In case zebra crash/restart, routes were not removed and the fpmsyncd will do the reconciliation later once zebra is back.

@zhenggen-xu Currently bgpd and zebra are killed explicitly for warm reboot.  If watchfrr is there, change may be needed to take watchfrr into account.
 
```
# Kill bgpd to start the bgp graceful restart procedure
debug "Stopping bgp ..."
docker exec -i bgp pkill -9 zebra
docker exec -i bgp pkill -9 bgpd || [ $? == 1 ]
debug "Stopped  bgp ..."
```
This PR can be cherrypicked for March/Nov branches
Can you please elaborate the issue you are trying to fix here?
@zhenggen-xu , this is a fix applied to 201803 branch to fix a jumbo frame (MTU > 1500) issue.
looks like #2163 changed this deliberately.
without #2163, if user is already in passwd file nss will not even communicate with tacacs. This is to address the scenario of user permission change

There does not seems to be a detailed explanation of the bug in the PR  https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/2163.

In short:
When a TACACS user login, indeed a passwd entry gets created, but with a *locked* passwd. This implies that when the same TACACS user logs in, he can't get in w/o reaching tacacs server. 

But say a TACACS user is logged in, and then his credentials are removed from TACACS servers, it would not affect his current session. But he can't create anymore new sessions.

So this restricts the nss access to only getting user info and nothing more. 

Hence compat first and TACACS next, should not affect the level of security in any way,

Later when we move on to controlling authorizations, I believe this, still would not impact as its impact is restricted to getpwnam, getpwent and related functions, with source of info from passwd file only.
the scenario is that user change from ro to rw, if we put compat first, will the user privilege gets updated after he changed from ro to rw on the tacacs side.
I have this question, why do you choose to compare the gecos? why not compare the group name of the tacacs user? it is going to be either remote_user or remote_user_su.

The strings "remote_user" & "remote_user_su" are not names of groups, but used to set pw_gecos (Full name) of the user.

The read-only users (privilege level = 1) get the  gid as "100", which is `users:x:100:user_ro` and rw users (privilege level = 15) gets gid=1000 which is `admin:x:1000:` as primary  group and "sudo,docker" as secondary groups.
why not for master branch?

Different SAI in 201811 and master.
It will be done in master as well.

Hi @jleveque 
 
According to your new API design document  (Azure/SONiC#285.)

> Appropriate platform-specific package will be installed during first boot, similar to platform drivers

Can you give me a suggestion about how to install this package to pmon during first boot ?
@jleveque Do you have any comment ?

@mudsut4ke: We currently do not have any examples to follow, but a couple vendors are working on their implementations. The idea is that your platform-specific `sonic_platform` package will be installed at first boot. The plan for now is to have the package reside in the `device/<vendor>/<platform>/` directory.

@jleveque So for now I should place sonic_platform package under `device/<vendor>/<platform>/` directory first 

Is that right ?
@mudsut4ke; Yes. For now, that is the location.
retest this please

@jleveque Can review the design ?
If it OK, I i will submit another API
